image.altText: Protesters at an anti-salmon farming rally on a beach.

props.synopsis: A Coalition government would not ban salmon farming in Tasmania's Macquarie Harbour even if the Maugean skate's threatened species' status is upgraded to "critically endangered", Peter Dutton says, as people take to the water in protest at the industry.

title.children: Dutton backs salmon farming even if threatened species status worsens

image.altText: Right side profile of a female tuba player.

props.synopsis: As a kid, Rachel Kelly saw "all the other girls play the flute" but after battling to make a decent sound on that, turned to the tuba â€” and now is doing what no other woman has done before.

title.children: Rachel may not one to blow her own horn, but others happy to celebrate orchestra's milestone

image.altText: Macaque monkeys.

props.synopsis: A visit to the 'monkey park' has been a part of this Tasmanian city's appeal since the late 1800s, so what is the history of Launceston's Monkey Island? And does it have a future?

title.children: How Launceston got its monkeys â€” and why they could be gone within decades

image.altText: Spirit of Tasmania IV ship in port.

props.synopsis: Tasmania's government has paid for double-page ads across three newspapers to address "frequently asked questions" about why the Spirit of Tasmania ferries are still a long way off operating â€” with Labor saying the ads are a "blatant waste" of money.

title.children: Ads explaining ferry debacle lashed as 'blatant waste' of money

image.altText: A sepia photograph of Amy Sherwin, who is side on to the camera, in 1887

props.synopsis: Known as the "Tasmanian nightingale", Amy Sherwin was Australia's first international opera singer. Today, she is relatively unknown, but there is a push to change that.

title.children: Australia's first big opera star sang for kings and died penniless

image.altText: Bauble in a celery top pine tree.

props.synopsis: A tree is central to many Christmas celebrations, but it doesn't have to be a one-hit-wonder dragged from storage each year or even one that is cut and then recycled after use. A botanist shares her tips on using potted native species.

title.children: Native species that fit the bill for a perfect Christmas tree alternative

image.altText: A satellite image of a large body of ice.

props.synopsis: Australian and international scientists have used satellite imagery to chronicle the collapse of a New York City-sized ice shelf in Antarctica, shedding light on key processes linked to future sea level rise.

title.children: Did you miss? ðŸ“£ Scientists now know how this ice shelf collapsed

image.altText: Pat Cummins high-fives Travis Head as he runs through in celebration

props.synopsis: Australia levels its five-match series against India with a comprehensive win in Adelaide as Pat Cummins finishes with a five-wicket haul in the second innings. Follow live.

title.children: Australia cruises to comprehensive win in Adelaide after Pat Cummins blows India away on day three

image.altText: Kim Garth of Australia celebrates a wicket, running and punching the air

props.synopsis: Centuries to Georgia Voll and Ellyse Perry have guided Australia to 8/371 in the second ODI against India in Brisbane. Follow live.

title.children: Australia on top as India chases a mammoth 372 to keep series alive

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: WICKET. ASH GARDNER GETS A WICKET
WICKET. MEGAN SCHUTT DISMISSES INDIA'S CAPTAIN

image.altText: An aerial view shows a West Bank Jewish settlement surrounded by bare mountains.

props.synopsis: Australia's stance against Israel's "unlawful" settlements in the Occupied Palestinian Territories is likely to impact the Future Fund's investments in business enterprises operating there.

title.children: Australia's opposition to Israel's 'unlawful' settlements set to impact Future Fund

image.altText: A man's hand drops a bottle containing a sperm into a woman's hand.

props.synopsis: Those powering Facebook's sperm exchange say they want options and they want control. But in this unregulated space, it's not always clear who's in control and who isn't.

title.children: Craig used Facebook to make a baby with strangers, then came torment

image.altText: A protester holds a placard during a rally.

props.synopsis: Protesters say they are angry and devastated as South Korea's parliament fails to pass a motion to impeach President Yoon Suk Yeol over martial law declaration.Â

title.children: Public outrage in South Korea as impeachment fails after vote boycott

image.altText: A map of Australia.

props.synopsis: As climate change progresses, the CSIRO has created the first detailed national maps to help Australians understand the future risk to their properties.

title.children: These maps reveal Australia's potential bushfire future for every postcode

image.altText: Australian teenage sprinter Gout Gout skips over the finish line well ahead of his rivals in a race.

props.synopsis: The family of Australian Olympian Peter Norman share their joy over Gout Gout's under-18 200m run at the Australian schools titles that broke Norman's famous record.

title.children: Peter Norman's family congratulates Gout Gout on record-breaking 200m

image.altText: Man putting food waste into a stainless steel drum

props.synopsis: Australia means so much to Iranian-born biotechnologist Sam Jahangard, he has made a huge sacrifice to keep his developments in the country instead of selling them internationally.

title.children: Scientist turns down $500 million to keep waste-to-compost invention in Australia

image.altText: The Notre Dame at dusk, with a projection on the side lighting it up in neon green, pink and light blue.

props.synopsis: The 860-year-old cathedral has been meticulously restored and reopened with a red carpet ceremony to the sound of the landmark's historic bells.

title.children: Notre Dame reopens with star-studded ceremony

image.altText: A long exposure shows a nuclear plant illuminated at night, with a white cloud of steam emerging from the top of two reactors.

props.synopsis: Amid a fierce political debate over energy policy, the Labor-led nuclear inquiry was seen as a tactic to discredit the Coalition's policy and stir up opposition in the regional communities where it wants to build reactors. But after weeks of public hearings, the Opposition is making the most of the opportunity to spruik its plans.Â

title.children: Labor's nuclear inquiry either a 'political stitch-up' or 'own goal'

image.altText: Sharn Freier poses for a selfie with some Matildas fans in Geelong.

props.synopsis: Sharn Freier was at a concert during the Matildas' dramatic penalty shootout win over France at last year's Women's World Cup. However she has since emerged as an outstanding prospect for the the team.

title.children: Matildas revelation Freier embraces her rapid rise

image.altText: A small white car surrounded by police tape.

props.synopsis: Two have been hospitalised with serious stab wounds after being attacked by a group of men in Melbourne's outer north-west on Saturday night.

title.children: Police investigate Melbourne stabbing spree

image.altText: Elderly man in striped shirt sitting in front of the King's Carriage

props.synopsis: Jim Frecklington, best known as the world's last royal coachmaker, has almost finished a 3-tonne gold-leaf embossed carriage for King Charles III despite undergoing treatment for cancer.

title.children: Craftsman with 'one of the rarest skills' nearly finished ride fit for king

image.altText: A man stands in a backyard with his arms crossed, looking into camera with a serious expression.

props.synopsis: Gambling reform advocates say greater action is needed to crack down on offshore gambling operators who are illegally targeting Australians, including recovered addicts.

title.children: Gambling companies accused of using 'loser lists' to target addicts

image.altText: Pedestrian walks past Reserve Bank building in Sydney

props.synopsis: The Reserve Bank of Australia hasn't changed the crash rate target for more than a year. Some economists reckon we won't see a cut for at least another few months.Â

title.children: Three of Big Four banks reckon rate cuts won't happen until autumn

image.altText: Sketch of school children at a large table. Four gathered at one end with a teacher and one alone at the other under a spotlight

props.synopsis: Raising a child with exceptional academic potential, perhaps destined solve the world's most pressing problems, sounds like a breeze. But even those who are identified as "gifted" can struggle to find the right path through school.

title.children: Gifted and ignored: The smart kids who can't afford to succeed

image.altText: Tiesha

props.synopsis: A survey finds more than half of people aged 18 to 29 with a credit card sign up solely to earn travel rewards points, but 60 per cent are struggling to clear their debts each month.Â

title.children: Discounted flights come at cost as young people fail to pay travel reward credit cards

image.altText: Beach at the Gold Coast with swimmer and surfers in the water.

props.synopsis: The wife of a paddleboarder seriously injured by a boat propeller at Currumbin Alley wants more signage warning of potential danger at popular surf breaks.

title.children: Fears of more boardrider versus boat collisions as Gold Coast crowds swell

image.altText: Portrait of three men against a dark theatre background.

props.synopsis: Jay Laga'aia is proud of his children, five of whom have followed him into show business. It's something he initially didn't want them to do.

title.children: Jay Laga'aia didn't want his kids to become performers

image.altText: A cardinal wearing cardinal robes standing next to a statue inside an old building in the Vatican.

props.synopsis: The Ukrainian-born missionary says he aims to be a cardinal who is "flexible, holy, accessible and without eminence".

title.children: Australian-based Ukrainian bishop now world's youngest cardinal at 44

image.altText: Phonics student writes word

props.synopsis: Primary school children are being taught the building blocks of language via a method that has had proven success overseas.

title.children: Victorian students to sit new test as part of move to 'phonics'

image.altText: Tom Gleeson standing with his arms crossed and a serious look on his face. The Hard Quiz has been added behind his head

props.synopsis: Call yourself a trivia master? Show us what you've got.

title.children: Think you're a big cheese when it comes to trivia? Prove it!

image.altText: An image of Vanessa Alford with her son Otis standing on a veranda with a leafy background

props.synopsis: Vanessa Alford moved across the country so her children could attend a primary school in Brisbane â€” one of very few that provides a specialist program for deaf and hard-of-hearing students. But what happens when kids go to high school?

title.children: Vanessa moved across Australia just so her kids could go to an inclusive school

image.altText: Three men on the verandah of the post disaster proto type at Southern Cross University

props.synopsis: Engineers hope easy-to-erect, sustainable cardboard homes may provide the answer to crisis accommodation after floods and bushfires.

title.children: Sustainable cardboard homes may provide post-disaster accommodation

image.altText: An English cyclist leads the way ahead of a rival in a women's sprint event on a velodrome.

props.synopsis: A British Olympic cyclist is taken to hospital but reportedly avoids serious injury after being launched over the barriers into the London Velodrome crowd with a rival during a big track cycling event.

title.children: Olympic cyclist flies into crowd in horror crash

image.altText: finished dish of corned beef and vegetables with a finishing sauce

props.synopsis: This is Alice Zaslavsky's take on a classic corned beef dish.

title.children: Corned beef with mash and mustard sauce
